title: health experts derail britain covid recovery
story: This dubious fad has split health experts, derailed the faltering post-Covid economic recovery and transformed us into faceless paranoid creatures.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesFar from encouraging ato work, pub le and shopping, face masks are stoking fears which have converted sceptical Britain into a nation of hypochondriacs.Instead of social harmony, we are being ided by confusing new masking rituals and instant anonymity. We are all aliens now.Just as herd immunity kicks in, infection risks drop to near-zero and scientists find new ways to keep us out of intensive care, neurotic Britain has gone into hiding.Boris Johnson warns this will continue until November “at the earliest”, with a chance of normality in time for a Christmas shopping spree.Fat chance. Nervous nellies love being scared.If we get any sort of winter flu — even without a second Covid wave and preposterous forecasts of , dead — many will stay indoors until spring  at the earliest.By which time, UK plc will be bankrupt, its economy broken in a thousand pieces.Everyone in authority has no doubt responded with the best of intentions to this shambles, including Public Health England.But come the inevitable public inquiry, this giant qango will find itself in the dock for unforced errors.The latest came last week when chief scientist Patrick Vallance blithely told MPs: “There is absolutely no reason to change advice to stay at home.”Let me to take you by the hand, Sir Patrick, and lead you through the streets of London.This is the fabled Square Mile, the global financial hub which, pre-Covid, generated half a trillion pounds a year —  per cent of the nation’s wealth.The capital usually attracts , visitors a day.Today it’s a ghost town, lucky to get ,.High-rise office blocks are empty. Street level stores, restaurants and coffee shops are locked and barred, some for ever. In pre-Covid times, you were rarely more than a couple of feet from someone in a hurry. Today you could fire a machine gun at rush hour and hit no one.That won’t change by , let alone by Christmas.Take a walk down Fleet Street, Sir Patrick, along the shuttered Strand, past Aldwych and mothballed theatreland.As Ralph McTell’s song goes, you might see an old man in the closed-down market kicking up the paper with his worn out shoes — yesterday’s paper telling yesterday’s news.That will be the London Standard, born in , fighting for its le.The governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, “shocked” by deserted London, warns of dire economic consequences. They are visible already.The Shard is empty. The lights are on in the Gherkin, the Walkie-Talkie and the Cheesegrater but nobody is home. St Bart’s hospital is empty, its thousands of heart and cancer patients left biting their nails with worry at home.Only the construction sites are busy, building brand new empty office blocks.At mainline stations you see more hi-viz jobsworths ordering passengers to wear masks than there are passengers.Firms want to reopen. But what’s the pointeveryone is too scared — or too idle — to come in. Many with secure jobs and salaries are undoubtedly skiving at everyone ’s expense.Only one in five civil servants, most on above-average salaries and gold-plated pensions, are bothering to come in.Are the rest all working energetically from home We are living in a state of collective hysteria, petried of a one-in-, chance of catching a bug which doctors have learned to make no more lethal than a bad dose of flu.The number of “excess deaths” — above the predictable national average — is now below normal.Yet we are staking the entire economy and the health, prosperity and le chances of our children and grandchildren on avoiding a risk which is less than being struck by lightning.THE BBC’s Andrew Marr deliciously caught China and ­Russia’s top envoys lying through their teeth.Beijing’s ambassador dismissed film of Uighur prisoners in chains and blindfolds as fake before squirmingly promising to “get back to you”. If he survives long enough, that is.Then Russia’s Andrei Kelin, a Michael Gove lookalike, shrugged off the Salisbury poisonings as a “dull” story and denied trying to steal our Covid vaccination formula.We believe you, comrades. But it might be a while before you are let loose on British TV again.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: instagram dogs getting paid 500 a day
story: Pet influencers are big news on Instagram, which means lucrative contracts from major brands.Even Formula One ace Lewis Hamilton has got in on the act – by signing his British bulldog Roscoe up for pet modelling and getting paid more than £ a day. Layla Flaherty set up pet modelling agency Urban Paws urbanpawsuk in  and represents , animals, from cats and dogs to parrots and llamas.The average rate for one of her models is £ but some have earned five-figure sums. Layla, , who lives in Liverpool with her Yorkshire terrier Mr Buttons, says brands love real animals that people can relate to, rather than posh pooches and cofured kitties.She says: “The most in-demand pets at the moment are mixed breeds, followed by the classic breeds, so it’s Airedale terriers, Jack Russells and the family breeds like labradors, retrievers and cockapoos. With cats, it’s always a moggy, a mixed-breed domestic cat.“Models need to be well-trained and socialised and able to work with actors.”Layla says some owners can be competitive when it comes to the careers of their precious pets, but welfare is always the top priority.She says: “You do get some as. Just like the dance mums, there are pushy pet parents.“If we feel someone is in this industry for the wrong reasons or pushing their dog too much, we have to put the animals’ welfare first and refuse to work with them. Thankfully most of our dog mums and dads are just more than happy to see their pets reaching lots of people.”Here, four proud owners tell RACHEL SPENCER what le is like when a canine’s career takes off.HE was found as a stray aged seven, suffered nightmares and PTSD and has been diagnosed with autism.Kenny’s owner Jane Tooms, , who adopted him from the Dogs Trust, believes he was previously kept locked away for many years.Now , Kenny’s love of routine and sharp focus means he is a great model.The Parson Russell terrier has a personal trainer and uses a treadmill, goes to a doggy dentist every six months and has monthly coat strips.He has worked with Kit Butler for HM, plus campaigns for Reebok, Aldi and energy company Equinor.Jane, from York, says: “Kenny didn’t have a nice le to start with and was taken back to the shelter many times.“But we revolve our lives around him and take him everywhere, including the sports store where we work, so he’s finally settled.“He’s a typical scruffy terrier but calm and placid. He loves wearing costumes and can sing on demand, shake paws and do a high five. I’m so proud of how he’s recovered, from having nightmares to being so happy and being a supermodel.“It’s like a fairytale ending for a rescue dog.”LOVEABLE Barry has worked with Pets At Home, Virgin Media, Sky Bet, Spoty, Firebox and Carpetright.Owner Nicole Lane, , from Birmingham, works in customer services and spends hours during days off chatting online to his , Instagram fans all over the world.Six-year-old Barry does not know any tricks but is calm and loves posing, so it is always easy to get the perfect shot.Nicole says: “I love spoiling him and he has around  dferent harnesses and bow ties.“He generally lives a very normal dog le, so his day is made up of walks, cuddles, snoozing – and posing for Instagram.“For his fourth birthday we had a pool party for  of his friends in a luxury Georgian manor house, with dogs on inflatables.“We raised money for Zoe’s Place, a local baby hospice.“My proudest moment was a photoshoot for Ava pet food, which is specically for pugs.“He was such a pro and took  minutes to get the shot.“Every time I go in Pets At Home I look at it and think, ‘I can’t believe it’s Barry’.”WHEN Rupert the cavapoo hears a camera click, he knows it is time for some tasty cheese or chicken.Owner Karen Power, , from Portsmouth, says he loves posing and staring into the camera. She decided to join a pet modelling agency after his Instagram page took off.Rupert, three, whose diet is mostly fresh food, has worked with Marks  Spencer, Not On The High Street, yappy and Fetch.Karen, who trained to groom the fluffy pup herself and takes him everywhere she goes, likes to “twin” with him, meaning they have  matching outfits.Rupert, who has , Instagram followers, has a further  bandanas and bow ties of his own.Karen says: “We got Rupert after my children had grown up and he is my world. Managing his social media and modelling is a full-time job, and he’s so eager to please.“He loves people and posing and focuses intently on the camera.“Our favourite job was when he had to eat spaghetti and meatballs sitting at the table of a posh London restaurant.“People were stopping and taking photos of the shoot.“Seeing him in the Christmas Marks  Spencer advert was such a proud moment.”THIS trio of impeccably trained golden retrievers have modelled for Dyson, Sainsbury’s, Vax, Ruffwear, Purple Bricks, Barbour, More Than Insurance and Primark.The family, who live with owner Suzy Cole, , in West Bridgford, Notts, comprises mum Lily, eight, and her pups Boris, five, and Mr Darcy, two.Suzy, a property developer and dog walker, has taught them tricks including walking backward on their rear legs, “say your prayers”, balancing on the base of her feet and hopping asinjured. When they are not modelling, the three dogs, who have nearly , Instagram followers, love splashing in mud and streams and even have their own bathroom and blow dry station.Coats are kept in top condition with a raw egg with each meal and they have  outfits, including Christmas pudding and Easter bunny suits, plus bandanas.They often go off exploring with Suzy and her boyfriend Aaron in their camper van. Suzy says: “We have been in the Arctic, in sub-C temperatures, watching a pod of  orcas and humpback whales from a boat.“They’ve seen the Northern Lights, been on a gondola in Venice and raced with us down a mountain skiing.“With their modelling and travelling, I’ve even had people say they wish they were our dogs!”DOUG the pug: instagram itsdougthepugGOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Trade group Make UK made the call as its research revealed more than half of companies in the sector were planning to cut jobs by the end of the year.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt warned of unemployment “on a scale not seen since the s”.Make UK’s Stephen Phipson said: “If we are to mitigate the worst impact of potential job losses, government must extend the furlough scheme for key strategic sectors to provide them with breathing space.”The group has also called for extra measures to be put in place to protect the aerospace and automotive industries.But Sir Ian Diamond - the UK’s top stat man and ONS - did not rule out a V shaped recovery to the economy.He said: Our data are showing that week on week people are saying they are more likely to go to a restaurant for example, so we will see the economy pick up, but how fast it will pick up with that V-shaped recovery, its too early to tell.But Make UKs latest survey revealed the number of companies planning to make redundancies in the next six months has risen to  per cent.It said this represents a continued sharp rise in firms intent to cut jobs over the past two months, rising from  per cent and  per cent in the two previous surveys.The sectors have seen thousands of jobs put at risk since the start of the pandemic, with the likes of Rolls-Royce, Meggitt and Jaguar Land Rover announcing major cuts.Almost a third of companiesare planning to make between  per cent and  per cent of employees redundant according to the group.It also reported that the proportion of companies expecting ato normal trading to take  months or longer has risen from just under a third in the previous survey to  per cent.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: photo wildebeest british nature photography prize
story: Andy Howe captured the image during the annual migration in Masai Mara, Kenya.Other runners-up and highly commended snaps include eagles scrapping over a fox carcass in Norway a cheetah about to leap on a baby gazelle and a hare leaping through a field in Cambridgeshire.Andy, from Suffolk, said of his winning shot: The image was taken during the Great Migration in Kenyas Masai Mara Reserve at a crossing point known as the Cup-de-sac.The throngs of Wildebeest, Zebra and Topi amass in their thousands creating a super herd on the banks of the Mara River, and they wait, building up their courage, energy, and motivation.It seems asthey will never do it, asthis is too large a barrier for them to cross.One courageous animal makes the first move, the first jump. title: tiktok perverts given one week suspension grooming children
story: Disgusted parents and campaigners have previously warned the app is a magnet for paedophiles after The Sun Online revealed children as young as eight were being targeted by predators and bombarded with sexually explicit messages.Leaked documents have now revealed TikTok only suspended users for a weekthey were caught messaging children in a sexual manner.That increased to a month for a second offence and then eventually a permanent ban when they were reported for a third time.Former moderators at TikTok told The Dailythis meant paedophiles were allowed back on the app with the same accounts, potentially allowing them to continue grooming children.Former moderators at the app said they were each told to prioritise monitoring up to , videos a day, rather than regularly checking reported messages.One ex-moderator said that while they had to view flagged videos within  minutes, reported messages would sometimes not be seen for days, with the backlog sometimes reaching more than ,.Former employees estimated around one in  messages flagged was due to adults messaging kids inappropriately and one ex-employee said that when they went into childrens accounts they sometimes saw as many as  dferent adults messaging them.The Childrens Charities Coalition on Internet Safety, an umbrella group for child protection organisations, called for a ban on TikTok from the UK.However Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said Britain had no plans to ban the app.It’s become a magnet for paedophiles as well as a hotbed for violent and extremist content, with TikTok predators exploiting the s young user base and lax security to prey on the vulnerable.Weve seen kids as young as eight being groomed on TikTok, while other creeps take advantage of young girls posting sexualised content of themselves on the .And thats especially worrying on a site which is attracting millions more children every year, with  per cent of kids now owning a smartphone by the age of seven.Thats why we launched our TikTok Time Bomb series — to make sure parents are aware of the risks their kids are being exposed to, and what they can do to better protect them. Everyone agrees social media can be a force for good, but it has to be used the right way and with proper controls in place.We want TikTok to better moderate its content so that it’s not being left to kids to protect themselves online. It comes as it emerged TikTok was considering London as its global HQ but is reconsidering because of tensions between the UK and Beijing.TikToks parent company ByteDance has been in discussions with officials from the Department for International Trade and No  to establish a worldwide base in Britain, creating , jobs.However The Sunday Times reported ByteDance has made the decision to suspend those negotiations due to the wider geopolitical context.It comes amid increasing tensions between London and Beijing, stemming from the UK Governments criticism of the Hong Kong security law and the recent decision to ban Huawei from the countrys G network.The Sun Online has previously reported how kids, often dressed in their school unorm, have been messaged by creepy strangers underneath videos of them performing to music.TikTok, which has been downloaded more than a billion times in  countries, is meant for those aged  and over. But its simple for users to lie about their age.Last year the Sun Online launched a TikTok Time Bomb series - to raise awareness of the risks and urge the site to be better moderated so kids are not left to protect themselves online.Campaigners have warned of the risks of young people falling prey to paedophiles on the app.Andy Burrows, NSPCC head of child safety online policy, previously told the Sun Online: Serious questions need to be asked about TikToks moderation practicesusers are able to freely post sexually suggestive comments to children.In response to the leaked documents detailing the companys policy for users found messaging children, TikTok said it has a zero tolerance approach to child abuse and the policies described by former moderators had since been updated.A spokesman for TikTok told the : Keeping people on TikTok safe is a top priority. Many of the claims brought to our attention refer to outdated practices, policies and processes that are no longer in place.We have a zero-tolerance response on child sexual abuse material and direct messaging is disabled for all under- users.All explicit and suspected grooming behaviours detected in direct messaging are escalated in a timely manner to our internal Child Safety Team based in Dublin to investigate the account.In line with best-practice international standards, we report all necessary information to the National Centre for Missing and Exploited Children or law enforcement, and ban the offending user.Restricted Mode ON:Family Safety Mode:Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: quarter brits could refuse take coronavirus vaccine
story: The troubling findings come ahead of results of an Oxford University trial which will show whether a jab it is developing is safe and triggers a immune fightback against coronavirus.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesShocking figures suggest  per cent of people could refuse the vaccine because they believe myths being peddled by anti-vaxxers.Research agency ORB International, which works with London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, last week surveyed , people across the UK.Those surveyed were askedthey agreed with the following statement: I would not want to be vaccinated against the coronavirusa high-quality vaccine were available.Some seven per cent of people strongly agreed they would not want to be vaccinated, and seven per cent agreed, while  per cent said they were undecided. Paul Hunter, professor of medicine at the University of East Anglia, told the Mail: The figures suggesting many people might refuse a vaccine are depressing, and actually incredibly selfish. If we get an effective vaccine, and almost everyone takes it up, overnight all the restrictions can stop and le willto normal like it was before March, with no social distancing or restrictions.There is a great deal of misinformation on the internet, and the risks of vaccines have been maliciously overestimated.Millennials are among the most susceptible to believe anti-vaccine conspiracy stories spread about on social media.The alarming finding comes amid a dramatic rise in the amount of anti-vax fake news being spread online.Anti-vax conspiracy theorists have a staggering  million followers online across the UK and US, new research from the Center for Countering Digital Hate has found.Yesterday anti-vaxxers joined hundreds of demonstrators in London’s Hyde Park who were protesting against the wearing of face masks.Face masks will become compulsory in shops from July  - and anyone who fails to wear one can be hit with a £ fine.One man was photographed wearing a white t-shirt that said: Save human rights, no to G, no to vaccinations, while another woman had the words question everything written on the front of her top.Virus experts say the coronavirus will only be beaten through “herd immunity”, which would be possible per cent of the population were vaccinated or had recovered from the illness.Meanwhile, the pandemic has found fresh legs around the world, as confirmed deaths pass , and countries from the U.S. to South Africa to India struggle to contain a surge of new infections. Hong Kong issued tougher new rules on wearing face masks, Spain closed overcrowded beaches and Germany reported another outbreak at a slaughterhouse.Pope Francis said the pandemic is showing no sign of stopping and urged compassion for those whose suffering during the outbreak has been worsened by conflicts.The World Health Organisation said that , new infections were reported on Saturday, its highest one-day Covid- case tally yet.In the UK, , people have tested positive for Covid- and , have died.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lockdown treasure finds roman pottery silver coin
story: They were unearthed as people spent more time pottering around at home.Finds include the arrowhead in Chithurst, West Sussex, a neolithic grain grinder in Bradford and medieval silver coin in Stoke, Staffordshire.Other objects discovered during lockdown include a post-medieval snake-formed belt hook in Herefordshire and a sandstone rock with an Ogham etched into it script, thought to be from the th Century, in Coventry.Archaeologists urge people not to be too embarrassed to asktheir finds are treasure or trash.Peter Reavill, a finds liaison officer, said: With so many people spending so much more time in their gardens, there have been some really interesting find.Ive seen some tobacco pipes, some pieces of pottery and even prehistoric flint tools found in peoples gardens.Brits are urged to contact the British Museums Portable Antiquities Scheme with their discoveries.Michael Lewis, from the British Museum, said: Finders can be shy about showing Finds Liaison Officers their garden finds, but we are keen to see what is discovered by the public.Often people dont realise the archaeological signicance of what they find.No lockdown discovery has been spectacular as the  US dollar gold coins found in Hackney, East London, in .Other impressive finds in Britain include a late medieval ring found on a molehill in Herefordshire and a gold lovers ring unearthed in a chicken run in Shropshire in .GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: covid vaccine uk deal pharmaceutical giants
story: A third of the Covid- treatments are being jointly developed by BioNTech and Pfizer - which is the first deal the two firms have signed with any government.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe second deal for  million vaccine doses is with French company Valneva and includes an option to acquire a further  millionthe vaccine is proved to be safe and effective.The clinical trials carried out by Valneva, which has a factory in Livingston, Scotland, are expected to be partly funded by the UK government.It has been reported that the funding will also allow the firms Scottish facility to expand allowing production of up to  million doses – some of which could be sold around the world.The Valneva remedy is an “ inactivated virus vaccine”, also known as a “killed vaccine”, which means it consists of virus pathogens which have lost their disease-producing capacity. Other vaccines use live pathogens which are still alive but are weakened.Downing Street has penned a third deal with AstraZeneca which gives the UK access to potentially one million doses of a treatment with Covid- neutralising antibodies.This jab could protect those who cannot be vaccinated such as people with weakened immune systems.In collaboration with the University of Oxford Astra Zeneca will work to produce  million doses for the UK in total.Health secretary Matt Hancock said a safe and effective vaccine is our best hope of defeating coronavirus and ing to le as normal.Experts this morning said that a new vaccine might not be suitable for all members of the population adding that the goal is to find a vaccine that prevents people from getting infected and that may stop levels of mortality. The three deals mean priority groups across all regions of the UK will be able to be vaccinated.Financial terms of the deals were not confirmed.Business minister Alok Sharma said: This new partnership with some of the worlds foremost pharmaceutical and vaccine companies will ensure the UK has the best chance possible of securing a vaccine that protects those most at risk.”There is currently no working vaccine against Covid-, the respiratory disease caused by the novel coronavirus, and experts say one will be needed to control the pandemic that has killed over , around the world.Speaking on BBC Radio  this morning Chair of the Vaccine Taskforce Kate Bingham said she was hopeful that a vaccine would be available before the end of the year but said it was all down to the data.“The Vaccine Taskforce is investing in a erse portfolio of vaccine candidates to maximise the chances of finding a vaccine quickly that meets the UK’s rigorous regulatory and safety standards. The fact that we have so many promising candidates already shows the unprecedented pace at which we are moving. But I urge against being complacent or over optimistic. The fact remains we may never get a vaccine andwe do get one, we have to be prepared that it may not be a vaccine which prevents getting the virus, but rather one that reduces symptoms.”She added that the UK has been at the forefront of the global race to find a vaccine.Speaking on the benefits of vaccination, she said people pushing an anti-vaccination message are not helping themselves or others.We are living in a world where we dont have millions of children dying in childhood. Vaccination has had a large benefit to society.If large numbers of people do not get vaccinated then the restrictions will have to remain.People in the UK have been encouraged to sign up to a new NHS website to make it quicker and easier for potential volunteers to join vital studies that could help save lives. title: hong kong treaty dominic raabs speech
story: But what will it be about and what time is it today  Here is everything youll need to know...The Foreign Secretary is expected to make the announcement to the House of Commons at midday today but the time has yet to be confirmed.The announcement will be available to watch on BBC Parliament and Sky News.Dominic Raab is expected to suspend the UKs extradition treaty with Hong Kong on Monday amid growing tensions with Beijing. According to the Daily , multiple Whitehall insiders claimed that the Foreign Secretary is set to tell MPs that the arrangement will be temporarily stopped.This after the imposition of the new national security law by the Chinese government last month. The Government has said China’s new national security law violates the Sino-British Joint Declaration which guaranteed Hong Kong’s way of le would remain unchanged for  years until .On Sunday Mr Raab accused China of gross, egregious humans rights abuses against the countrys Uighur population.He said: “It is clear that there are gross, egregious human rights abuses going on, which is why in Geneva at the UN we raised this with  partners ... to call out the government of China for its human rights abuses of the Uighurs, also of Hong Kong.Mr Raab also described the reports of forced sterilisation and mass reeducation camps as deeply troubling. It follows the government’s decision to exclude the tech giant Huawei from the UK’s G network, in a major U-turn just six months after approving its involvement.The Chinese ambassador to the UK, Liu Xiaoming, said Beijing was still considering its response but warned Britain not to get drawn into a “tit-for-tat” confrontation.Britains extradition treaty with the Chinese government criminalises any Hong Kong nationals who have dealt in secession, subversion and collusion with foreign forces. It also curtails rights to protect and freedom of speech. These rules apply outside of Chinas borders causing fears that Beijing could try and use the extradition treaty to drag overseas residents involved in pro-democracy activism back to Hong Kong. title: vaccines critical workers
story: The Education Secretary Gavin Williams today praised the new deal with pharmaceutical companies and promised Britains health professionals would get access to any vaccine first.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAppearing on Sky News, the senior minister claimed vaccines were the most important weapon against the pandemic.He said: There is not a single silver bullet but we do have to recognise the vaccine is the safest and best route of this crisis.It is right that the government is making the investment and placing these orders with these vaccines so we have a range of options.The first stage will obviously be those critical workers, and there will be a basis of assessment, but its about making sure we have vaccines for the whole population.It comes after UK secured early access to  million coronavirus vaccine doses currently undergoing Phase  trials with pharmaceutical companies.A third of the Covid- treatments are being jointly developed by BioNTech and Pfizer - which is the first deal the two firms have signed with any government.The second deal for  million vaccine doses is with French company Valneva and includes an option to acquire a further  millionthe vaccine is proved to be safe and effective.The clinical trials carried out by Valneva, which has a factory in Livingston, Scotland, are expected to be partly funded by the UK government.Downing Street has penned a third deal with AstraZeneca which gives the UK access to potentially one million doses of a treatment with Covid- neutralising antibodies.This jab could protect those who cannot be vaccinated such as people who with weakened immune systems.The three deals mean priority groups across all regions of the UK will be able to be vaccinated.There is currently no working vaccine against Covid-, the respiratory disease caused by the novel coronavirus, and experts say one will be needed to control the pandemic that has killed over , around the world.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the luminaries start bbc cast about
story: The cast of the six-part period drama series includes Sin Citys Eva Green, with the novel adaptation weavinga tale of love, magic, revenge and the lust for gold.The Luminaries began on Saturday, June , on BBC One.The six-part, suspenseful drama is based on the Booker Prize-winning novel of the same name.After airing in weekly instalments, the final episode of the hit period drama is on tonightat pm.In addition to this, the full series of The Luminaries is also available on BBC iPlayer.The show is an adaption of Eleanor Cattons Man Booker Prize winning novel, which gained a string of plaudits when it won literatures most prestigious awards in .Cattons novel, which stands at a whopping  pages long, was hailed for being intriguing, daring and full of wonder on first publication.The books premise concentrates on characters set within the wild west coast of southern New Zealand during the time of its gold rush.Full of clfhanger chapter-endings, it kept readers turning pages as they delved deeper into the th century story, chronicling the development of the new world.The synopsis reads: The Luminaries tells an epic story of love, murder and revenge, as men and women travelled across the world to make their fortunes.It is a th century tale of adventure and mystery, set on the Wild West Coast of New Zealand’s South Island in the boom years of the s gold rush.The story follows defiant young adventurer Anna Wetherell, who has sailed from Britain to New Zealand to begin a new le.There she meets the radiant Emery Staines, an encounter that triggers a strange kind of magic that neither can explain. title: dominic cummings tough brexit deal
story: The PM’s chief adviser is driving the UK’s tough approach to no compromise in the talks, according to EU insiders.Diplomats in Brussels fear he is sabotaging Boris Johnson’s hopes of wrapping up a trade agreement swtly.Multiple EU sources told The Sun of growing concern Vote Leave veterans in the PM’s inner circle want a “pure” no deal break.They have pinpointed deputy negotiator Oliver Lewis, who is a close ally of Mr Cummings, as a key blockage in the talks.He has been accused of repeatedly moving to shut down progress whenever openings have looked possible.Mr Lewis, who was Vote Leave’s research director and is now the PM’s no deal adviser, has been nicknamed “the political commissar” by EU insiders.But British officials insist the pair are just being realistic about the kind of deal No  can get through the Commons.And they emphatically denied suggestions any of the PM’s team are trying to block an agreement.There is still a strong belief in Brussels that Mr Johnson wants to seal a deal and get Brexit done and dusted in the Autumn.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: selfie black bear mexico
story: The hikers kept their cool when the curious bear approached them from behind on a trail in Mexico.The encounter reportedly happened at a popular hiking trail at Chipinque Ecological Park in San Pedro Garza García, according to a person who shared the video. Footage shows a woman standing very still as a black bear, perched on its hind legs, approaches and snfs her.Behind her, two other female hikers manage to remain calm as they watch the bear inspect their friend.The animal briefly drops onto the ground, but suddenly lurches back onto its hind legs again and presses himself against the woman. Bystanders try to distract the black bear - however, its preoccupied with snfing the womans head. Meanwhile, the woman quickly seizes the unbelievable moment and pulls out her phone to take a selfie.   Ascompletely aware, the bear stands just long enough for the picture before dropping back on all fours and lightly swatting at the womans legs twice. The black bear then begins to wander away, while the woman and her friends speed out of the area. The shocking moment was shared to social media, where it amassed more than two million views since Saturday.Former NBA player Rex Chapman shared the video on his page and wrote: Oh. my. goodness. She’s a rock. I want this girl in my foxhole...The user who shared the video noted that it wasnt uncommon to see black bears in Chipinque Ecological Park, and its certainly not the first time it was caught on camera. Last December, two black bears terried a visitor in the park while snfing around garbage cans for food. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsUK set to tear up Hong Kong extradition deal in move likely to inflame China tensionsThe Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab has insisted Britain wants a "positive relationship" with China but Downing Street looks set to follow the example of the US and impose a tough new national security lawShareCommentsByGavin CordonRyan Merrield:,  JUL NewsForeign Secretary Dominic Raab has insisted Britain wants a positive relationship with China " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailForeign Secretary Dominic Raab is to set out further measures in response to Chinaaposs imposition of a tough new national security law on Hong Kong amid growing tensions. The Government looks likely to follow the example of the US, Canada and Australia and suspend the UKaposs extradition treaty with the territory - a move that would infuriate China. In a strong signal that he is ready to go down the same route, Mr Raab confirmed at the weekend that he had completed a review of Britainaposs extradition arrangements as part of the next steps. China was already smarting over the Governmentaposs decision last week to exclude the tech giant Huawei from the UKaposs G network - reversing a decision in January allowing it a limited role. Mr Raab threatened to pour further fuel on flames, accusing the communist regime of committing gross, egregious human rights abuses against the countryaposs Uighur population in the north-western Xinjiang province. The criticism was furthered by the chair of the defence select committee, Tobias Ellwood, who said Britain has been duped over the last couple of decades by China. The Chinese ambassador to the UK, Liu Xiaoming, said Beijing was still evaluating its response to the Huawei ruling.  There were reports at the weekend that the the Chinese social media company TikTok had broken off talks to open a global headquarters in Britain. Communist Party officials were also reported to have warned UK companies operating in China, including Jaguar Land Rover, BP and GlaxoSmithKline, that they could now face retaliation. Mr Liu warned Britain not to get drawn into a tit-for-tat confrontation in the way the US had, imposing sanctions on Chinese officials over alleged abuses in Xinjiang, prompting Beijing to sanction a number of US senators and officials. Mr Raab played down suggestions any such measures were imminent under the UKaposs new independent sanctions regime, saying that it took a long time to build a case against any alleged abusers. He insisted also that Britain wanted a positive relationship with China, working with it on issues such as climate change as well as trade and investment.

title: universal credit claimants extra cash
story: NewsUniversal Credit claimants to get extra cash as DWP cuts five-week wait - for someMinisters have bowed to pressure and will give legacy benefit claimants two weeks of "run-on" payments - helping bridge the five week gap. But millions of new Universal Credit claimants will not benefit - and Citizens Advice say its not enoughShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL News " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMinisters have finally bowed to pressure and will effectively cut the five-week wait for a first Universal Credit payment - for some people. Anti-poverty campaigners have long called for the Department for Work and Pensionsto scrap the rule, which means claimants must wait five weeks for their first payment – or take an advance which must be repaid. The Government today said thousands of claimants moving onto UC – the Conservativesapos flagship welfare overhaul – will receive up to two weeksapos worth of additional cash during the five-week gap. But the announcement does not cover the millions of people who come on to UC as new benefit claimants. Instead, it will only help those who move onto UC from legacy benefits which they were already claiming. Dame Gillian Guy, Chief Executive of Citizens Advice, said: “Run-on payments are a welcome step that will lighten the burden for many legacy benefits claimants moving to Universal Credit. “But millions of people who have lost their jobs as result of this crisis remain subject to the five-week wait.  While advances are available, they have to be repaid, which can leave people with a choice of struggling now or struggling later. “Turning advance payments into a grant would strengthen the safety net and make sure more people don’t face hardship or debtthey need support from Universal Credit.” From Wednesday,someone’s existing claim of income-based jobseeker’s allowance, income-related employment and support allowance or income support ends due to them applying for Universal Credit, they will receive a payment worth up to two weeks of their “legacy award” – the benefit they were on previously.The one-off payment is designed to help people during their first assessment period and, crucially, does not have to be paid back. It will be paid automatically to eligible claimants when they claim UC for the first time and will not affect the amount of UC they receive. Welfare Minister Will Quince said: “This one-off payment will provide additional support as claimants move from legacy benefits to Universal Credit. “It doesn’t have to be paid back and won’t affect their UC award, so is welcome extra cash in pockets.” UC rolls six welfare benefits – child tax credit, working tax credit, jobseeker’s allowance, income support, employment support allowance and housing benefit – into a single payment. It has been blighted by delays and cost overruns. In February it emerged the full rollout had been delayed again, adding £million to its overall cost.

Desperate tourists are stuck in the Philippines, Bali and India – which has been rocked by power cuts and monsoons. Lorry driver Peter Howlett and partner Debbie Reilly arrived in Goa in February for a three-week stay. They are now £, out of pocket after being there five months and having to rent an apartment. The state on India’s south west coast has a strict three-day lockdown in place after a surge of , cases caused by partygoers flocking to the beaches. The couple say the UK government’s £million repatriation effort has “dried up”. Tourists struggling to arrange their own flights find them quickly filled up or, frequently, cancelled. Peter, , said: “It’s beyond a joke. “I’ve been furloughed, so I haven’t missed shts. But as UK businesses are starting up again I worry what that’ll mean for me. “ Coronavirus is getting worse here and we’ve been forgotten.” Are you still stranded abroad  Email webnews@mirror He said they had to stop paying bills at home in south west London to cover their costs. They were booked toon Air India on March  – but the airline halted all UK flights just four hours before take-off. Dad-of-two Peter, a diabetic, had to have a £ cataract op this month in Goa, while mum-of-three Debbie, , is battling depression. They are among hundreds of Brits still stranded in India, which has had more than a million cases and , coronavirus deaths. Gran-of-five Maxine Rainback also arrived in February. Her April was cancelled – as were three more flights she booked. She is booked to fly from Goa in two weeks but fears being grounded againlockdown there is extended.  Both Maxine and Peter say they contacted the British Embassy for help when it began repatriating , nationals in April. They say they have “heard nothing” since. Some £ flights are available through national carrier Air India – but from Mumbai,  miles away, or Delhi, nearly , miles distant. Maxine, , from Salford, has lung condition COPD, while partner Tom Marsden, , had a triple heart bypass two years ago. She said: “We can’t risk travelling by train or taxi to those cities.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA self-employed hairdresser has won the right to claim for notice, holiday and redundancy pay in what her lawyers claim is a landmark case for thousands of beauty industry workers. Meghan Gorman, , won an Employment Tribunal judgment in her favour after arguing that, although she had a contract as a self-employed hairdresser, the amount of control over her working practices effectively made her an employee. Ms Gorman, from Clitheroe, Lancs, claimed she had to work the hours set by the salon, who kept % of her takings. She worked for six years at a Terence Paul salon in Manchester city centre until it closed in . Her lawyers claim the judgment in her favour, following an Employment Tribunal hearing in Manchester, furthers recent legal decisions on worker status in the case of Pimlico Plumbers at the Supreme Court and Uber drivers, currently on appeal from the Court of Appeal. Judith Fiddler, of Direct Law  Personnel, said the preliminary judgment could affect thousands of hairdressers nationwide and other people such as dentists, hygienists, delivery drivers and bookkeepers. Ms Fiddler added: The whole hairdressing industry and many others will be affected by this decision. The signicance is huge, as many people who think they are self-employed are actually not. The influence of the Pimlico Plumbers and Uber driversapos cases has changed the climate. Our case was that Meghan was treated as an employee and was not genuinely self-employed, and therefore should benefit from employment law rights. At all times she was treated as an employee and her bosses exercised tight control over all aspects of her work. Around , people work in the beauty industry in the UK, more than % of them women, according to industry figures. Employment Tribunal Judge Marion Batten ruled in Ms Gormanaposs favour in March, with the reasons for the ruling released this week. Ms Gorman is now to pursue other claims against Terence Paul including unfair and wrongful dismissal, sexual discrimination and a failure to provide a written contract of employment, as well as claiming for holiday pay, her lawyers said. She joined Terence Paul, which at the time operated six luxury salons, as a -year-old trainee in  and later began work on a contract headed Independent Contract for Services as a self-employed hairdresser. Terence Paul claimed the companyaposs self-employed hairdressers had control over the hours and days they worked, their starting and finishing times, treatments they could give and their holidays. Ms Gorman disputed this, saying she had to work from am-pm from Monday to Saturday, had no control over pricing or offering discounts, had to use the companyaposs products, conform to Terence Paulaposs standards of dress, and had to tell the salonshe wanted time off. Ms Gorman said: They clearly had the power and control. I did not believe it could be considered I was in business on my own account.

title: mum two drops three dress
story: NewsMum-of-two drops three dress sizes in her sleep - and says its down to £. appStacey Orton, , who has battled with eating disorders, decided to change her le after looking at herself in a work photograph - and has lost lb in just five weeksShareCommentsByErin CardfJamie Hawkins:,  JUL NewsStacey Orton says a £. hypnosis app made her drop three dress sizes in her sleep " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . Dont miss our must-read newsletterWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA beauty expert who has struggled with her size for most of her le revealed how she dropped three dress sizes in her sleep – thanks to a £. hypnosis app. Suffering with the eating disorder bulimia nervosa in her twenties, mum-of-two Stacey Orton, , of Gateshead, Tyne and Wear then became a comfort eater. But she was shocked into action two years ago by a photo revealing her ballooning size, posted on her work Instagram account, which left her feeling mortied. Noticing that a colleague had shed lb in two weeks using a virtual gastric band, Stacey, who was then a size , weighing st lb, said: “He had been visibly losing weight and had managed to sht about half a stone in two weeks. “I asked him how he did it and he told me about this app by  Weeks to Wow called ‘Virtual Gastric Band Hypnosis – Lose Weight Fast.’ I downloaded it myself as soon as I went on my lunch break that same day.” To her amazement, ft in Stacey - whose body mass index, which is used to gauge a healthy weight, was ., compared to the NHS recommended range of . to ., making her obese - shed a whopping lb in five weeks after playing it every night as she fell asleep. Now weighing just st lb, wearing a size  and having lost an incredible . inches from all over her body, Stacey said: “I’ve always struggled with my weight in one way or another. “But now I have completely transformed my mindset around food. I feel happy with myself and that need to stress eat has gone. I’m stronger than ever, these days. “I still have my down days, but listening to the app calms me down. For me, it’s about so much more than just the physical weight loss.” Stacey, who is a single mum to McDonald’s worker Andrew, , and college student Ryan, , first began to struggle with food aged . For years, she suffered with bulimia – an eating disorder which sees people binge eating, before either making themselves sick, using laxatives or excessively exercising in a bid to stop gaining weight - making her so ill that, at her worst, she was on the brink of being hospitalised. But when she fell pregnant with Andrew, she forced herself to deal with her demons, saying: Something like bulimia never fully goes away, but you learn to get it under control. “For me, the turning point was getting pregnant. I had this little le inside me that I needed to protect. I had to change my ways and stop damaging my body for the sake of my unborn baby.” For a while after Andrew arrived, new mum Stacey felt content and happy with her size. She added: “I wasn’t worried about my weight in the slightest. As I was breastfeeding, I made sure I ate really healthily, too.” When, just under two years later, she split with her ex-husband while she was pregnant with Ryan, sadly, everything changed. Dealing with a orce and a newborn baby took its toll on Stacey, although the stress saw her losing weight. “It just fell away. I was so stressed I could barely eat,” she said. But, despite her love for her children, as the years passed, depression kicked in and Stacey started comfort eating takeaways and junk food, as she tried to boost her mood. When ious slimming plans failed, she simply accepted her hefty frame, saying: “I was actually quite okay with the way I was – or at least, I thought I was. “Food stopped being a comfort blanket and became something I ate as a treat to make me happy. I know now that’s still emotional eating, though.” Her turning point came in early  when she spotted an unflattering photo on Instagram. She continued: “As I work in beauty, we take a lot of photos of makeup and that sort of thing to share on Instagram. “I noticed one of myself, and it didn’t sit well with me. I’d felt comfortable with who I was, but seeing that picture felt, to me, like I was letting myself go. Thankfully, the hypnosis app was her saviour and the morning after she first used it, the results were already plain to see. She said: “I went to a work coffee morning, where they were giving out cakes and biscuits. Usually I’d have loved it, but something in my mind had switched and I just didn’t want to eat them.” Since then, Stacey has continued to lose weight and is now a svelte size . Her diet has completely transformed and she has ditched takeaways, snacks and junk food in favour of healthy, home-cooked options. Starting the day with granola and berries, she will now make protein-packed lunches and dinners, like chicken and rice with vegetables, or prawn linguine. She said: “I don’t even keep junk in the house anymore and I’m not one for a takeaway these days. “I can’t quite explain the app as I’m often asleep before it gets to the hypnosis part, but it helped me to re-examine my eating habits entirely. “Listening to it, I would envisage my thinner self, looking at my reflection in the mirror, and imagine all the unhealthy stuff I put in my body being laid out on a table, pushed away, and replaced by healthy options. “I’ve learnt to eat what I want, not what I can. I don’t keep shovelling food in until I’m past full and uncomfortable, anymore. “The way I eat is much more instinctive now. I’ll listen to when I’m actually hungry rather than eating because I think I should. “I even use a smaller plate to eat off, so I’m not tempted to pile my portions high like I used to.”

Laura Lomas, sister on ward , said Mr England would get himself up and dressed each morning before the therapist teams arrived, so that when he needed to exercise he could ask to walk to see his we. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThis weekend was an incredible , days since Princess Elizabeth became our Queen. To celebrate Saturday’s momentous milestone, we look back at  highlights from her reign and discover some hidden gems courtesy of Ingrid Seward, editor of Majesty magazine and royal biographer. . Becoming Queen  Young Princess Elizabeth was in Kenya at Treetops Hotel on February , , when she became Queen on the death of her father, George VI. Ingrid says: “Within two hours of hearing the news they were ready to leave for the airport. “There was a lot of working press waiting there and they stood in attention, with box cameras at their feet, as a mark of respect for the young Queen’s grief.” . The Coronation The crown was offocially placed on the new Queen’s hed on June, ,  in Westminster Abbey, becoming the th Sovereign to be crowned there and the th Queen. A whopping million people in the UK watched it. Ingrid says Prince Philip “kissed her on the cheek and was a little clumsy and slightly shted the crown - apparently she had to slightly adjust it. It was a really intimate touch on the most formal of occasions.” .   World Tour  The Queen set off on a seven month tour of the Commonwealth - her longest ever - in November  and visited  countries in the West Indies, Australasia, Asia, and Africa, covering more than , miles. Charles and Anne stayed at home. Ingrid says: “The children were being looked after by their grandparents and the Queen and Philip used to send diplomatic bags with recordings in them so the children could hear their voices.” . Charles’ investiture The Queen crowned Prince Charles on July ,  at Caernarfon Castle in Wales. One of the stars of the show was the Queen’s hat of yellow silk, with a crown entirely embroidered with pearls and bugle beads. “After some problems with putting his coronet together the designers had to improvise - using a gold-plated ping-pong ball to complete the work” Ingrid says. . Birth of Andrew  Andrew was the first of Elizabeth’s children to be born while she was reigning. He appeared on February ,  at .pm, weighing lb oz. Like Charles, Andrew was born at Buckingham Palace, but this time the Queen had her baby in the Belgian suite. “A few days before his birth a decree was issued saying that from henceforth the Queen’s children would use the surname Mountbatten-Windsor,” Ingrid says. . US visit  Aged , the Queen was greeted at the White House by President Dwight Eisenhower, above - the first serving president she met during her reign. During the tour, the royal party watched an American football game where the Maryland Terrapins defeat the North Carolina Tar Heels -. On their way back to the White House, they stopped in at the supermarket at the queen’s request. Ingrid says: “They became close - so close she sent the President her recipe for scones.” . Moon landing message  During the Apollo  moon landing in , astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin, above, carried — and left behind on its surface — a silicon disk containing messages of peace and goodwill from many world leaders. The Queen’s message to the Moon read: “On behalf of the British people I salute the skill and courage which have brought man to the moon. May this endeavour increase the knowledge and well-being of mankind.” “The Queen has always loved the excitement of space travel. She and Prince Philip are fascinated by it” Ingrid says. . First Tweet  In , while opening the Information Age exhibit at London’s Science Museum, the Queen, referring to herself as Elizabeth R., tapped out her first tweet from the official Twitter account of Buckingham Palace.“The Queen was slow with technology to start with and it was Andrew who used to set the video for her” says Ingrid. “But by  she was Tweeting and now she’s doing Zoom calls…” .  First filmed Christmas message  The Queen’s  Christmas Broadcast was an historic event, as it was the first to be televised. It was also the th anniversary of the first Christmas Broadcast on the radio. The broadcast was made live from the Long Library at Sandringham, Norfolk. Ingrid says: “She was so nervous that it took Philip to go and stand behind the camera where he told a few daft jokes and got her to relax.” .  Charles’ engangement Their engagement became official on February ,  - and the Queen was delighted. She believed Diana was ‘one of the family’ and was pleased Charles had found someone. “The Queen wrote to one of her friends saying she was delighted that Charles had become engaged to the Spencer girl, she’s one of us” Ingrid says. . Olympics   After her star turn at the opening ceremony - she took little persuading from Danny Boyle to appear in a short sequence alongside Daniel Craig’s James Bond - the Queen was awarded an honorary BAFTA. According to her dresser Angela Kelly, she agreed immediately to star in the sequence as long as she could say the iconic line Good Evening Mr Bond. “When they walked about taking the engagement photos at Buckingham Palace the Queen was watching out of the window.” . Golden Wedding On November ,  The Queen and Prince Philip celebrated their Golden Wedding anniversary, attending a lunch at Banqueting House in London. The Queen made a speech in which she looked back on ‘a remarkable  years’ and paid tribute to the man who was her “strength and stay.” Ingrid says: “It said everything about her relationship with her husband. It was very important to her because that was the year Diana died and the state of the monarchy had been rocky.” . Golden Jubilee  The Queen’s Golden Jubilee in  saw her tour the country, visiting  cities and towns in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland in  counties over  days. She also headed overseas - clocking up more than , miles including trips to Jamaica, New Zealand and Australia and drawing huge crowds wherever she went. “The Queen is always very moved when her subjects come out and see her and she really loved it” says Ingrid. “Nowadays she complains that she never sees their faces anymore because they’re all holding up cameraphones.” . First grandchild Princess Anne’s son Peter Phillips was born on November , , at St Mary’s Hospital in London. Royal insiders say Peter is still his grandma’s favourite - and he’s often talked about their close relationship. “She was just about to conduct an investiture when she got the news” says Ingrid. “Very out of character, she held up the investiture for  minutes then apologised for being late due to the birth of her first grandchild!” . Friendship with Reagan  In , celebrations for the th anniversary of the Allied landings in Normandyduring the Second World War took place. Insiders say the Queen was extremely moved by the events - as well as a memorable speech from Ronald Reagan who she had become friendly with during his time as President. “Although they were an unlikely friendship she was fond of Reagan and they shared some memorable moments” Ingrid says. “They had a mutual interest in horses.” . Diamond Jubilee The year  marked the th anniversary of accession. The only Diamond Jubilee celebration for any of Elizabeth’s predecessors was in , for Queen Victoria. Her Majesty set two ground rules for the festivities: the use of public funds should be minimised and people should not “be forced to celebrate”. “She worries about making people celebrate her milestones - she’s very humble” Ingrid says. . Harry and Meghan  The Queen liked Meghan when they met in  and the feeling was mutual. Meghan said: “When I met her I had such a deep understanding and of course incredible respect for being able to have that time with her. And she’s an incredible woman.” Ingrid says: “Despite what followed, the Queen still has affection for the pair, although she is saddened by losing their input into royal le.” . Wills and Kate The Queen was heavily involved with the wedding in  - even down to choosing William’s outfit - an Irish Guards unorm. She later declared the whole day to have been ‘excellent’. “The Queen was overjoyed by Kate and wanted to offer them the most wonderful wedding they could have” says Ingrid. “She basically let them have Buckingham Palace for the night-do.” . Launch of Britannia  The Queen launched her beloved Royal Yacht Britannia from the John Brown shipyard in Clydebank on April , . Britannia conveyed the Queen, other members of the Royal Family and ious dignitaries on  foreign visits and  visits in British waters and steamed ,, nautical miles. “Always very poignant to her because it was going to be made for her father” says Ingrid. “She says it’s the only place she could ever be herself.” . Birth of George The Queen loves all the new additions to the royal family. But George’s arrival in  was a pretty special one - and she’s doted on him since then. Her Majesty leaves presents at the foot of his bed when he visits Buckingham Palace. George calls his -year-old grandmother “Gan Gan.” “When she first went to visit George after his birth she couldn’t believe how noisy he was because he never stopped crying” Ingrid reveals. “But she loves him.” .  World Cup  The Queen opened the World Cup in England during the opening ceremony at Wembley Stadium. And she was back just a few weeks later to present captain Bobby Moore with the Jules Rimet trophy as England beat West Germany -. “It was good fun - she’s not the biggest football fan but she knew what a shot in the arm it was for us win” says Ingrid. . Burmese the horse So loved was Burmese that she was given the unusual honour of being buried on the grounds of Windsor. She was presented to the Queen by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Her Majesty rode her at Trooping the Colour for  consecutive years from  to . “Her love of horses was epitomised in that no-one  was ever allowed to ride her” says Ingrid. “In , when shots were fired at the Queen while she was riding at Trooping the Colour her first thought was for Burmese.” . Ascot winner  The Queen is a huge fan of horse racing and even takes part in the £ sweep in the Royal Box at Ascot. The high point of her career as an owner came at Ascot in  with her horse Estimate, a four-year-old who won the Gold Cup. Estimate’s victory was the first time the Gold Cup had been won by the reigning monarch. “This was probably one of her greatest days ever for someone who is incredibly knowledgeable about racing and breeding” says Ingrid. . th birthday  In  Elizabeth celebrated her th birthday. She lit a beacon which set in train a series of over  beacons across the country and worldwide. As well as her celebrations in April, the country held a giant street party for , people. “She always says ‘If I stop I drop’ and she’s got no intention of stopping” Ingrid says.

The nationwide study has revealed the majority of Brits are enjoying more garden parties this year as a safe way to see friends while social distancing. And in a new list of must-have ingredients for a successful outdoor event, a BBQ with sausages is the number one, according to % of respondents. Quiche Lorraine, pasta salads and scotch eggs also made the list, as did bunting and games of rounders. The survey of , adults also found % now believe an outdoor party should have a fire pit. While % think leaving blankets out for your guests, for when it gets cold, is a nice touch. More than one in twenty have even wowed their guests by hiring DJ decks and outdoor cinema screens. As many as % of those surveyed feel the garden party is more popular this year because it is easy to socially distance, while % feel they have been cooped up for so long, they want to enjoy sitting in the garden with friends. A quarter said a garden party is the best way to enjoy the great British Summer, while % feel the garden party has seen a resurgence this year.

title: stars back bid virus remembrance
story: NewsStars back bid for virus remembrance day to ease pain of those who couldnt say goodbyeFamous faces have come out in support of the Sunday Mirror and end-of-le charity Marie Curie UKs campaign to get Boris Johnson to declare national day of mourning next MarchShareCommentsByJulie McCaffreyHalina WattsNigel NelsonJanine YaqoobGrace Macaskill :,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsRicky Gervais has said that everyone needs time to grieve and heal " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCelebrities and politicians have called on Boris Johnson to honour those who have died during the pandemic with a national day of remembrance. After Le star Ricky Gervais, Gavin  Stacey’s Alison Steadman and Strictly’s Craig Revel Horwood are among the famous faces backing a campaign to commemorate the lives of those who have died during lockdown. Labour, the Lib Dems and the Tories have thrown their weight behind the bid launched by the charity Marie Curie UK and backed by the Sunday Mirror. Comedian Ricky, who plays a grief-stricken husband in After Le, said: “Everyone needs time to grieve and heal. “The pandemic has meant thousands of people haven’t been able to say goodbye to loved ones in the way they would have wanted. Many haven’t got to hold their nearest and dearest. To have a day that officially honours those people – in whatever form – would be a wonderful celebration of their lives.” More than , people died in the UK during lockdown – equating to one million people bereaved. From March to June, , were recorded as “excess deaths”, including more than , coronavirus victims. Grieving families were unable to comfort each other, with mourners limited to between  and  people at crematoriums and ­graveyards. Most funeral homes were unable to offer viewings. Marie Curie, which gives support to ­families living with terminal illness, wants the Government to mark the UK’s loss on the first anniversary of lockdown, March , . Chief executive Matthew Reed said it would be“an ­important reminder of our responsibility to our communities”. They have launched a petition to get people to support the idea with the hashtag #UniteInMemory, with almost , people adding their signatures so far. The charity is keen to look at ideas for an “inclusive” act of remembrance. This could range from a service such as the one observed for Remembrance Sunday, or a communal act such as the Thursday night clapping that rang out for NHS workers during lockdown. The charity’s ambassador Alison Steadman lost a relative to Covid-. Alison, , said: “The funeral was delayed and there could only be a small number of people. I worry there will be a tide of emotion from people bereaved and they will carry that throughout their lives.  “After going through the scariest period of our letime, a special day could be something nice to come out of the pandemic, just like the Thursday night NHS claps and all the kind deeds.” Actor Greg Wise, ­comedian Paul Chuckle and commentator Chris Kamara echo her call. Strictly judge Craig Revel Horwood suggested Britain could shut for a day to “pause and remember”.  He said: “When this pandemic passes there’s a risk people will forget about it quickly but it should be remembered and those we lost should also be remembered.” Presenter Paul O’Grady said: “Families saw loved ones get into an ambulance and, for many, that was the last time they saw them. There’s been no real closure for people, they’ve just been left dazed. A day like this would help ease the pain.” Loose Women star Coleen Nolan said it was “important we recognise the sense of grief suffered by so many”. She said: “It would give them some comfort to know the rest of Britain stands in solidarity.”  Ex-EastEnder Debbie Arnold and former Corrie star Sherrie Hewson, who present YouTube hit The ­Wonderbirds, also back it. Sherrie’s brother Brett Hutchinson died at the age of  in April from a brain tumour and she could not see him in his final hours. She said: “I’ll always look back at  as the most horrendous year of my le.  “There should be a big street party. The pain is hard but I’d like to remember him on a joyous occasion.” The campaign also had the backing of major political parties. Labour Deputy Leader Angela Rayner said: “Losing a loved one is always devastating, but losing someone without even being able to say goodbye must be unbearable.  “The Government should back a national day to reflect.” Lib Dem leadership hopeful Layla Moran said people had “experienced devastating losses” and urged the Government to introduce the day. Tory MP Andrew Bridgen said: “We should include all those who have passed and remember close friends and family whose funerals we were not able to attend.” Families are touched by the campaign. Jenny Wilson, , of Belfast, lost her mum Karen, , to throat cancer and her funeral was held on the first ­official day of lockdown. She said: “We’d no time to remember Mum and were left with a gaping hole of grief. I hope a national day will honour everyone who didn’t have the funeral they deserved.”

title: when to wear face masks
story: NewsWhere you do and dont need to wear a face mask as gym-goers exempt – rules explainedFitness enthusiasts will be free to work out at the gym without wearing a mask as face coverings become compulsory in UK shops and supermarketsShareCommentsByLaura Sharman:,  JUL NewsA woman wears a mask at a hair salon " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailGym bunnies are the latest group to be exempt from wearing face masks leading to mounting confusion among Brits on when to wear them. With further easing of lockdown restrictions, people do not have to wear a mask while at the office, working out at the gym or socialising at a pub or restaurant. But face coverings are compulsory when travelling by public transport or visiting shops and supermarkets. Boris Johnson announced a string of measures to reduce the risk of spreading the virus when gyms, leisure centres and swimming pools reopen on July  but wearing face masks is not one of them. Fitness enthusiasts will not have to wear face coverings while working out at the gym when centres reopen after the coronavirus lockdown.UK guidelines for wearing face masks are looser than countries such as Spain where people are required to wear a mask on the beach and at swimming pools, except when eating or swimming. But the new rules seem to be conflict with Government demands to wear masks in enclosed public spaces and make them compulsory in shops from Friday leading to growing confusion. The latest UK government advice says face masks are strongly encouraged in enclosed public spaced when coming into contact with people you do not normally meet. It also states you must wear a face covering at all times on public transport or when attending a hospital as a visitor or outpatient. UKactive, representing Britainaposs gyms and leisure centres, told MailOnline it spent last week in talks with Ministers to set guidance for its , member firms. The industry body said it is ensuring the fitness sector is aligned to Government guidance in the lead up to its reopening. But a spokesperson said UKactive would not expect face coverings to become mandatory in our facilities including , leisure centres, swimming pools and gyms. It says this is according to World Health Organisation guidance that people should not wear masks while exercising indoors as they may be less able to breathe comfortably. A build up of sweat on face mask materials could also encourage the growth of microorganisms, it states. Fitness chains have been preparing to reopen with new safety measures to protect members against coronavirus including limited visitor numbers, regular deep cleaning, and staff temperature checks. Virgin Active members will not have to wear face masks when most of its  UK gyms open on Saturday. David Lloyd also confirmed face masks will not be compulsory in its  UK health clubs. A UKactive spokesperson said: We note the Government’s decision on face coverings on shops and public transport where it is harder to keep social distancing in place. However, we also support the Government’s consideration that there need to be practical requirements for each sector. As such, when it comes to gyms and leisure centres, the appropriate mitigation measures will be in place to make sure that social distancing remains. Therefore we would not expect face coverings to become mandatory in our facilities. Wearing a face mask does not protect you from coronavirus, according to Government advice.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA woman who recovered from coronavirus says she was asked to leave a hair salon for not wearing a face mask properly. Lisa Brookfield, , left the premises halfway through an appointment in tears after what she described as discrimination. She left Mark Jeffs Hair  Beauty Studios in Lincoln after revealing she had suffered three waves of Covid- before making a recovery in May. Concerns were raised that Lisa, who has suspected asthma, was refusing to wear a mask properly, and the appointment was ended at the hair washing stage.The salon offered to blow dry her hair and re-arrange an appointment, but Lisa stormed out with her hair dripping wet feeling humiliated and went to another salon, LincolnshireLive reports.Lisa, who wanted her hair to look nice for a dinner with a friend on Friday evening and her first date in a year, said: The salon refused to cut my hair because I mentioned I have previously had Covid - three waves of it with the last one being in May. I left the salon with my hair dripping wet and in tears. They askedI wanted it blow dried and said I will just do it myself when I go home. I think what happened to me is a form of discrimination. I had Covid months ago and itaposs not fairI cannot access services. I went to another salon in a village and they said they were all right to cut peopleaposs hairthey had had Covid. Lisa, a forensic psychologist from With St Hughs, said she had originally booked her appointment for .am but the salon contacted her to say her usual stylist was not available. A new appointment was arranged for .am the same day. Lisa admits that she was  minutes late because she mistakenly thought the cut was scheduled for .am. The salon was able to accommodate her later on. Lisa said: I went in to reception and askedthey wanted me to wear a mask and I was offered a mask.  When I went through I mentioned to the hair stylist who was going to cut my hair that I likely have asthma and a mask restricts my breathing. I askedit was all rightI pulled it down slightly and the stylist said that was ok. I said I had actually had Covid three times, meaning I had had three waves of it. As another person was washing my hair, a stylist came through and said Mark Jeffs had made a decision that because I had had Covid, the appointment could not continue. I had just been saying how good their protective procedures and equipment were. I got up with wet hair wrapped up in a towel and went to reception. Mark told me: aposYou wonapost wear a mask.apos. I said that was not accurate and that I would wear a mask but it restricts my breathing. Then he said I was  minutes late and I apologised and said it was human error. He said I was being threatening but I was not. Miracle Boyd, , was at a protest to pull down a Christopher Columbus statue in Chicago when she was struck in the face. Video shared on social media shows the moment the -year-old was hit. In the video, a police officer is seen nearing the teen before swinging his fist at her and apparently making contact with her face. Other footage shows her aggressively confronting police officers at the protest. Boyd was recording an argument she had with a cop when he allegedly hit her, ABC reported. My tooth was knocked out, she told the outlet. I have lip abrasions in my mouth. My teeth hurt really bad. According to a GoFundMe organised to help cover her medical expenses, Boyd had just spoken to a crowd of protesters at Grant Park when the incident occurred.
